newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission says U.S. starch subsidy talks planned.
newsitem.headline: Commission says U.S. starch subsidy talks planned.

text.p: Consultations with the United States on European Union wheat starch production refunds are envisaged if the EU's market share rises significantly beyond 1992 levels, a European Commission spokesman said on Wednesday.

The spokesman was commenting after U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Monday said her agency launched an investigation into allegations that EU subsidies for modified starch were hurting U.S. producers.
"The situation needs to be clarified. It's difficult to assess the size of the U.S. market," the commission spokesman said.
The U.S. Wheat Gluten Industry Council alleged that EU wheat starch subsidies benefited European production and export of wheat gluten to the United States.
Gluten and starch are wheat by-products.
The EU exports about 25,000 tonnes of wheat gluten annually to the U.S., compared with imports of six million tonnes of American corn gluten feed, the EU spokesman noted.
The USTR investigation under Section 301 of U.S. trade law could take up to 180 days, U.S. sources said.
